page.title: 15WOODLAND ECOLOGY:LOWESWATER
page.content: The woodland has been National Trust owned since 1936. Half of the trees are of the soft wood variety e.g. Pine. These are grown commercially for fencing material and also to be pulped for paper. Deciduous trees make up the other half e.g. Oak. It is N.T. policy to preserve the woodland in its' natural state. There are two fulltime and ten temporary workers employed as foresters. Horses were used up to 1982 to move timber from steep areas, but this is now fully mechanised. Local wildlife includes badgers,red squirrle, roe deer, foxes and wild mink. Mink are not native to this country, but have escaped from farms to which they were imported and bred for their fur. They are hunted because they upset the balance of the natural fauna.
